tit.cmt: jo補足 他ファイルと合わせる

sen.j: 佐和山城（さわやまじょう）は滋賀県彦根市（近江国犬上郡）にある山城跡。
sen.e: Sawayama Castle was a mountain castle (of which almost no trace remains today) and was located in Hikone city in Shiga Prefecture (what was once Inukami county of Omi province).
Sawayama Castle was a mountain castle (of which almost no trace remains today) and was located in Hikone city in Shiga Prefecture (what was once Inukami county of Omi province).
Sawayama-jo Castle was a mountain castle (of which almost no trace remains today) and was located in Hikone City in Shiga Prefecture (what was once Inukami County of Omi Province).
sen.cmt: jo補足 他ファイルと合わせる地名表記

sen.j: 犬上郡のみならず近江支配の重要拠点であり、16世紀の末には石田三成が居城としたことでも知られる。
sen.e: It was a key strongpoint that controlled not only Inukami county but all of Omi province, and is famous for being the seat of power of the daimyo Mitsunari ISHIDA at the end of the sixteenth century.
It was a key strongpoint that controlled not only Inukami county but all of Omi province, and is famous for being the seat of power of the daimyo Mitsunari ISHIDA at the end of the sixteenth century.
It was a key strongpoint that controlled not only Inukami County but all of Omi Province, and is famous for being the seat of power of the daimyo Mitsunari ISHIDA at the end of the sixteenth century.

sen.j: 佐和山城を築城したのは鎌倉時代の豪族・佐保氏とされる。
sen.e: The earliest version of Sawayama castle was erected during the Kamakura period by the Saho clan, a powerful family at that time.
The earliest version of Sawayama castle was erected during the Kamakura period by the Saho clan, a powerful family at that time.
The earliest version of Sawayama-jo Castle was erected during the Kamakura period by the Saho clan, a powerful family at that time.
sen.cmt: jo補足 他ファイルと合わせる

sen.j: 戦国時代(日本)には浅井氏の支城となり、元亀年間には浅井氏の家来である城主磯野員昌が織田信長らと激戦を繰り広げた。
sen.e: During the Sengoku (warring states) period, the castle fell under the control of the Asai clan; during the Genki era (1570-1573), the overlord of the Asai clan, Kazumasa ISONO, began a fierce conflict with Nobunaga ODA.

During the Sengoku (warring states) period, the castle fell under the control of the Asai clan; during the Genki era (1570-1573), the overlord of the Asai clan, Kazumasa ISONO, began a fierce conflict with Nobunaga ODA.

During the Sengoku Period (Period of Warring States), the castle fell under the control of the Asai clan; during the Genki era (1570-1573), the retainer of the Asai clan and lord of the castle, Kazumasa ISONO, began a fierce conflict with Nobunaga ODA.
sen.cmt: Sengoku (warring states) period→Sengoku Period (Period of Warring States)overload→retainer of the Asai clan and lord of the castle,

sen.j: しかし1571年（元亀2年）2月に磯野は降伏し、代わって織田氏配下の丹羽長秀が入城し、近江国犬上郡および若狭国支配の拠点とした。
sen.e: But in the second month of 1571, the Isono clan surrendered, and Nagahide NIWA, a vassal of the Oda clan, occupied the castle, taking the place of the Asai clan, controlling Inukami county and Omi province as well as Wakasa province from there.

But in the second month of 1571, the Isono clan surrendered, and Nagahide NIWA, a vassal of the Oda clan, occupied the castle, taking the place of the Asai clan, controlling Inukami county and Omi province as well as Wakasa province from there.

But in the second month of 1571, the Isono clan surrendered, and Nagahide NIWA, a vassal of the Oda clan, occupied the castle, taking the place of the Asai clan, controlling Inukami County Omi Province as well as Wakasa Province from there.

sen.j: 1582年（天正10年）6月の本能寺の変の後に行われた清洲会議では、明智討伐に功があった堀秀政に与えられ、その後、堀家の転封にともない堀尾吉晴が入城した。
sen.e: At the Kiyosu Council, which occurred in the sixth month of 1582 following the Honnoji Incident (in which Nobunaga died, betrayed by his vassal Mitsuhide AKECHI), the castle was awarded to Hidemasa HORI, who had won distinction during the hunting down of the Akechi forces, but thereafter, following a transition of the leadership of the Hori clan, it was Yoshiharu HORIO who occupied it.

At the Kiyosu Council, which occurred in the sixth month of 1582 following the Honnoji Incident (in which Nobunaga died, betrayed by his vassal Mitsuhide AKECHI), the castle was awarded to Hidemasa HORI, who had won distinction during the hunting down of the Akechi forces, but thereafter, following a transition of the leadership of the Hori clan, it was Yoshiharu HORIO who occupied it.

At the Kiyosu Council, which occurred in the sixth month of 1582 following the Honnoji Incident (in which Nobunaga died, betrayed by his vassal Mitsuhide AKECHI), the castle was awarded to Hidemasa HORI, who had won distinction during the hunting down of the Akechi forces, but thereafter, following a transition of the leadership of the Hori clan, it was Yoshiharu HORIO who occupied it.

sen.j: さらに、1590年（天正18年、ただし入府時期には異説あり）には五奉行の一人である石田三成が入城した。
sen.e: Still later, starting in 1590 (though theories differ as to precisely when he entered and began ruling there), Mitsunari ISHIDA, one of the Five Commissioners, took over rulership of the castle.
Still later, starting in 1590 (though theories differ as to precisely when he entered and began ruling there), Mitsunari ISHIDA, one of the Five Commissioners, took over rulership of the castle.
Still later, starting in 1590 (though theories differ as to precisely when he entered and began ruling there), Mitsunari ISHIDA, one of the Five Commissioners, took over rulership of the castle.

sen.j: 三成は大規模な改修工事を行い、山頂に五層（三層説あり）の天守が高くそびえたつほどの城を築き、「三成に過ぎたるもの二つあり、島左近と佐和山の城」と言わしめた。
sen.e: Mitsunari launched a large-scale repair project, constructing a towering castle with a five-storey (others claim it was a three-storey) central donjon on the mountain's summit, leading to the saying "Mitsunari outdid himself twice, with Kiyooki SHIMA and with Sawayama Castle."

Mitsunari launched a large-scale repair project, constructing a towering castle with a five-storey (others claim it was a three-storey) central donjon on the mountain's summit, which lead to the saying "Mitsunari outdid himself twice, with Kiyooki SHIMA and with Sawayama Castle."

Mitsunari launched a large-scale repair project, constructing a towering castle with a five-storey (others claim it was a three-storey) central donjon on the mountain's summit, which lead to the saying 'Mitsunari outdid himself about two things, Sakon SHIMA and Sawayama-jo Castle.'
sen.cmt: jo補足 他ファイルと合わせる人名修正twice→two things島左近は1回と数えられる出来事ではないので修正

sen.j: 但し、三成は奉行の任を全うするために伏見に滞在することが多く、実際に城を任されていたのは父の石田正継であった。
sen.e: But Mitsunari was often away at Fushimi in order to fulfill his duties as Commissioner, so the one actually entrusted with the running of the castle was Masatsugu ISHIDA, his father.
But Mitsunari was often away at Fushimi in order to fulfill his duties as Commissioner, so the one actually entrusted with the running of the castle was Masatsugu ISHIDA, his father.
But Mitsunari was often away at Fushimi in order to fulfill his duties as Commissioner, so the one actually entrusted with the running of the castle was Masatsugu ISHIDA, his father.

sen.j: 三成は関ヶ原の戦いに万が一敗北した場合を考え、佐和山城で再戦を意図していたとされる。
sen.e: It is thought that Mitsunari, contemplating what to do if the worst occurred and his side was defeated in the battle of Sekigahara, planned to regroup at Sawayama Castle and continue the war from there.

It is thought that Mitsunari, contemplating what to do if the worst occurred and his side was defeated in the battle of Sekigahara, planned to regroup at Sawayama Castle and continue the war from there.

It is thought that Mitsunari, contemplating what to do if the worst occurred and his side was defeated in the battle of Sekigahara, planned to regroup at Sawayama-jo Castle and continue the war from there.
sen.cmt: jo補足 他ファイルと合わせる

tit.cmt: jo補足 他ファイルと合わせる

sen.j: 1600年（慶長5年）9月15日 (旧暦)の関ヶ原の戦いで三成を破った徳川家康は、小早川秀秋軍を先鋒として佐和山城を猛攻撃した。
sen.e: Ieyasu TOKUGAWA, who on the fifteenth day of the ninth month of 1600 defeated Mitsunari at the battle of Sekigahara, sent Hideaki KOBAYAKAWA to lead the vanguard and begin a fierce assault on Sawayama Castle.

Ieyasu TOKUGAWA, who on the fifteenth day of the ninth month of 1600 defeated Mitsunari at the battle of Sekigahara, sent Hideaki KOBAYAKAWA to lead the vanguard and begin a fierce assault on Sawayama Castle.
Ieyasu TOKUGAWA, who on October 21, 1600 defeated Mitsunari at the battle of Sekigahara, sent Hideaki KOBAYAKAWA to lead the vanguard and begin a fierce assault on Sawayama-jo Castle.
sen.cmt: グレゴリ歴にjo補足 他ファイルと合わせる

sen.j: 城の兵力の大半は関ヶ原の戦いに出陣しており、守備兵力は2800人であった。
sen.e: The majority of the castle's forces had been sent away to fight in the battle of Sekigahara, leaving the garrison's strength at 2800 men.
The majority of the castle's forces had been sent away to fight in the battle of Sekigahara, leaving the garrison's strength at 2800 men.
The majority of the castle's forces had been sent away to fight in the battle of Sekigahara, leaving the garrison's strength at 2800 men.

sen.j: 城主不在にもかかわらず城兵は健闘し敵を寄せ付けなかったが、やがて城内で一部の兵が裏切り敵を手引きしたため奮戦空しく落城。
sen.e: Despite the fact that the lord of the castle was absent, the garrison fought very spiritedly and prevented the enemy from drawing close, but soon after one portion of the garrison betrayed their comrades, switched sides and guided the attackers into the castle, rendering vain all the hard fighting and making surrender inevitable.

Despite the fact that the lord of the castle was absent, the garrison fought very spiritedly and prevented the enemy from drawing close, but soon after one portion of the garrison betrayed their comrades, switched sides and guided the attackers into the castle, rendering vain all the hard fighting and making surrender inevitable.

Despite the fact that the lord of the castle was absent, the garrison fought very spiritedly and prevented the enemy from drawing close, but soon after one portion of the garrison betrayed their comrades, switched sides and guided the attackers into the castle, rendering vain all the hard fighting and making surrender inevitable.

sen.j: 三成の父・正継や三成の妻など一族は皆戦死・自害して果てた。
sen.e: The battle lost, Mitsunari's father Masatsugu, his wife, and his other family members all either died fighting or killed themselves.
sen.cmt: I added "The battle lost" to make it clearer why they would have killed themselves.
sen.e: The battle lost, Mitsunari's father Masatsugu, his wife, and his other family members all either died fighting or killed themselves.
The battle lost, Mitsunari's father Masatsugu, his wife, and his other family members all either died fighting or killed themselves.

sen.j: 徳川方の兵士は「栄華を極めた三成はさぞ華美を尽くしたのだろう」と思い、我先にと城内に乱入したが、城の壁は粗壁であり、また何の装飾もない質素な作りとなっていたという。
sen.e: The story goes that the soldiers in the Tokugawa army, thinking "Since Mitsunari possessed such luxury, surely the castle will be completely full of wondrous splendors," each scrambled to be the first to break into the castle, but they discovered the castle had plain, unadorned walls, and was in fact a very spartan building without any decorations at all.

The story goes that the soldiers in the Tokugawa army, thinking "Since Mitsunari possessed such luxury, surely the castle will be completely full of wondrous splendors," each scrambled to be the first to break into the castle, but they discovered the castle had plain, unadorned walls, and was in fact a very spartan building without any decorations at all.

The story goes that the soldiers in the Tokugawa army, thinking 'Since Mitsunari possessed such luxury, surely the castle will be completely full of wondrous splendors,' each scrambled to be the first to break into the castle, but they discovered the castle had plain, unadorned walls, and was in fact a very spartan building without any decorations at all.

sen.j: しかも、三成邸にあったものは豊臣秀吉から送られた感謝状のみであったと伝わっている（『甲子夜話』）。
sen.e: Indeed, it is said (in the "Kasshi yawa" or "Evening Talks of the Kasshi-cycle Year") that the only thing of note in Mitsunari's mansion was a letter of thanks sent to Mitsunari from Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI.

Indeed, it is said (in the "Kasshi yawa" or "Evening Talks of the Kasshi-cycle Year") that the only thing of note in Mitsunari's mansion was a letter of thanks sent to Mitsunari from Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI.
Indeed, it is said (in the "Kasshi yawa" (Evening Talks of the Kasshi-cycle Year)) that the only thing of note in Mitsunari's mansion was a letter of thanks sent to Mitsunari from Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI.
sen.cmt: 英語説明補足スタイル

sen.j: 石田氏滅亡の後、徳川四天王の一人である井伊直政がこの地に封ぜられ入城した。
sen.e: After the annihilation of the Ishida clan, Naomasa II, one of the Four Heavenly Guardians of the Tokugawa clan, was sent to clamp down on the area, and occupied the castle.
After the annihilation of the Ishida clan, Naomasa II, one of the Four Heavenly Guardians of the Tokugawa clan, was sent to clamp down on the area, and occupied the castle.
After the annihilation of the Ishida clan, Naomasa II, one of the Four Heavenly Guardians of the Tokugawa clan, was sent to clamp down on the area, and occupied the castle.

sen.j: 三成は領地で善政を敷いており、領民からも大変慕われていたので、直政はその威光を払拭するため新たに彦根城築城を計画した。
sen.e: Mitsunari had exercised benevolent government throughout his territory, making the people on his lands dearly miss him, so Naomasa planned to build a new castle at Hikone in order to sweep away all memory of Mitsunari.

Mitsunari had exercised benevolent government throughout his territory, making the people on his lands dearly miss him, so Naomasa planned to build a new castle at Hikone in order to sweep away all memory of Mitsunari.

Mitsunari had exercised benevolent government throughout his territory, making the people on his lands dearly miss him, so Naomasa planned to build a new castle at Hikone in order to sweep away all memory of Mitsunari.

sen.j: しかし、直政は築城に着手できないまま1602年（慶長7年）に死去したため、嫡子の井伊直勝がその計画を継ぎ、佐和山城などの築材を利用して建造した彦根城が完成した。
sen.e: But Naomasa died in 1602 before construction had even begun, and so his heir Naokatsu II took over the construction plans, recycling many of the building materials used in Sawayama castle in order to complete construction of Hikone castle.

But Naomasa died in 1602 before construction had even begun, and so his heir Naokatsu II took over the construction plans, recycling many of the building materials used in Sawayama castle in order to complete construction of Hikone castle.

But Naomasa died in 1602 before construction had even begun, and so his heir Naokatsu II took over the construction plans, recycling many of the building materials used in Sawayama-jo Castle in order to complete construction of Hikone-jo Castle.
sen.cmt: jo補足 他ファイルと合わせる

sen.j: 1606年（慶長11年）に直継が彦根城に移ったため、佐和山城は廃城となった。
sen.e: After Naokatsu moved his seat of power to Hikone castle in 1606, Sawayama castle was abandoned.
After Naokatsu moved his seat of power to Hikone castle in 1606, Sawayama castle was abandoned.
After Naokatsu moved his seat of power to Hikone-jo Castle in 1606, Sawayama-jo Castle was abandoned.
sen.cmt: jo補足 他ファイルと合わせる

sen.j: ほとんどの建造物は彦根城に移築したり破却されたため城跡には残っていないが、石垣と土塁の一部などが現在も残っている。
sen.e: Because virtually all of the materials that had originally been used to construct Sawayama castle were removed and reused in the construction of Hikone castle, almost no trace of Sawayama castle remains today, though portions of its old wall and earthen embankments can still be seen.

Because virtually all of the materials that had originally been used to construct Sawayama castle were removed and reused in the construction of Hikone castle, almost no trace of Sawayama castle remains today, though portions of its old wall and earthen embankments can still be seen.

Because virtually all of the materials that had originally been used to construct Sawayama-jo Castle were removed and reused in the construction of Hikone-jo Castle, almost no trace of Sawayama-jo Castle remains today, though portions of its old wall and earthen embankments can still be seen.
sen.cmt: jo補足 他ファイルと合わせる

sen.j: その他
sen.e: Other notable details concerning Sawayama castle
Other notable details concerning Sawayama castle
Other notable details concerning Sawayama-jo Castle
sen.cmt: jo補足 他ファイルと合わせる

sen.j: 彦根城築城400年祭のイベントとして2007年9月1日～16日までの期間限定で佐和山一夜城復元プロジェクトが開催された。
sen.e: For a limited time only, from September 1-16, 2007, as one of the events celebrating the 400th anniversary of Hikone castle's construction, a project restoring Sawayama castle to its old appearance was held.

For a limited time only, from September 1-16, 2007, as one of the events celebrating the 400th anniversary of Hikone castle's construction, a project restoring Sawayama castle to its old appearance was held.

For a limited time only, from September 1-16, 2007, as one of the events celebrating the 400th anniversary of Hikone-jo Castle's construction, a project restoring Sawayama-jo Castle to its old appearance was held.
sen.cmt: jo補足 他ファイルと合わせる
